data.text: But thou, our God, art gracious and true,
For if we sin, we are thine, knowing thy power:
For to know thee is perfect righteousness:
For neither did the mischievous invention of men deceive us,
The sight whereof enticeth fools to lust after it,
Both they that make them, they that desire them, and they that worship them,
For the potter, tempering soft earth,
And employing his labors lewdly, he maketh a vain god of the same clay,
Notwithstanding his care is, not that he shall have much labor,
His heart is ashes, his hope is more vile than earth,
Forasmuch as he knew not his Maker,
But they counted our life a pastime,
For this man, that of earthly matter maketh brittle vessels and graven images,
And all the enemies of thy people, that hold them in subjection,
For they counted all the idols of the heathen to be gods:
For being mortal, he worketh a dead thing with wicked hands:
Yea, they worshiped those beasts also that are most hateful:
Neither are they beautiful, so much as to be desired in respect of beasts:
